reviewText: After watching the 1st season of Covert Affairs last summer on USA, I was left with mixed feelings.  The show has a great look, sets and a beautiful and athletic lead actress in Piper Perabo as CIA agent Annie Walker.  Also, the show has a solid creative team behind it led by producer Doug Liman, who was responsible for the Bourne movies.  However out of the 11 episodes, I can honestly say I only enjoyed maybe 5 or 6 at most.  The show was marred by sloppy writing and an inconsistent plotted serialized arc about Annie and a mysterious ex-boyfriend.  When it comes to a rookie show like this, you can expect some growing pains.  There were several other issues I had which included miscasting Sendhil Ramamurthy from Heroes as Jai Wilcox, an Indian-American CIA agent, who helps Annie on several missions.  They also tried to make him a potential love interest for Annie and you can tell right away he had no chemistry with Perabo.  The show also wasted the talented Anne Dudek from House and Mad Man, as Annie's sister who had no clue she's a CIA agent.  And I'm not sure I understand why the writers chose to make Chris Gorham's character Auggie blind.  To me, it added nothing to the show.  Am I supposed to feel sympathy for him?  The character had some chemistry with Annie, but I didn't become attached to him right away.  He did grow on me as the season progressed.  There was another serialized arc in season 1 about a possible leak in the CIA, which went nowhere and had a disappointing resolution.  The show did have some great guest stars including Peter Gallagher, who played a top CIA official, Greg Itzen, Oded Fehr and Eriq LaSalle.After watching the CW show Nikita this past season, I was even more disappointed with Covert Affairs.  Nikita delivered wall to wall action and a very compelling serialized arc with great characters.  Covert Affairs on the other hand, left me with the feeling of what could have been.  Hopefully the writers learned from their mistakes and will make the show compelling this season.  As for purchasing this DVD set, I would wait until there is a significant price drop.

reviewText: Finally, a TV show about a female spy that ISN'T all about dressing her in sexy clothing. Instead, "Covert Affairs" is all about a young CIA agent's adventures, as she carries out taut, action-packed missions. It's an enjoyable, promising little series, and Piper Perabo makes an enjoyably earnest young agent.Annie Walker (Perabo) is undergoing training to be a CIA agent, and trying to forget her last romance -- her boyfriend Ben (Eion Baile) vanished without a trace, and she hasn't been able to find him.Then she's suddenly pulled out of the program, stationed in Washington, and sent out into the field to use her linguistic skills. So when she isn't trying to have a semi-normal social life and spending time with her sister's family, Annie is diving into some very hard missions under the guidance of blind agent Auggie (Christopher Gorham).She has to deal with a boy-genius, a deadly Venezuelan agent, a disastrous Zurich mission, a Senatorial leak, a computer hacker who wreck's D.C.'s communications, an Iranian refugee, smugglers, an art auction.... and the return of her former lover. At the same time, her bosses have discovered that someone inside the CIA is leaking information to a muckraking journalist.Disclaimer: I am not a CIA agent, and I don't know what it's like to be one. But I assume that "Covert Affairs" is a pretty good dramatic depiction of that agency -- there are some obvious flaws (husbands and wives cannot work together in government agencies), but it FEELS much more realistic than many other shows' depictions of the CIA.Every episode has a nice tight mesh of action, drama, and a bit of humor, as Annie grapples with life-threatening scenarios, hails of bullets, villainous agents and the possible deaths of innocents. But somehow she always manages to save the day, and the writers make sure to stay connected to her life with her family (such as when Annie's sister tries to set her up on a date).It also helps that Piper Perabo makes a really likable heroine -- Annie is a very earnest, sensible, kind young protagonist, but she also can kick butt. Gorham is a pretty awesome sidekick for her, especially since it's rare to see a disabled person in a TV show like this one. And we have some solid performances by Peter Gallagher and Kari Matchett as Annie's bosses (who are also stormily married), and the megahot Sendhil Ramamurthy."Covert Affairs Season One" is a tight, action-packed little series with a likable heroine and some solid stories. Give it a try, and tune in next season.

reviewText: The USA Network stumbled onto a good thing when it debuted the offbeat MONK back in 2002, but it quickly picked up on its now trademark winning formula. Not too long after, the "Characters welcome" slogan began making its rounds. Nowadays, the USA Network, with its very strong programming, has become an influential player in televisionland. MONK is gone now, but PSYCH, WHITE COLLAR, SUITS, IN PLAIN SIGHT, and BURN NOTICE follow the tradition of compelling, quirky characters who anchor highly watchable shows. COVERT AFFAIRS continues the splendid streak. It introduces - and, for some, re-introduces - Piper Perabo whom the camera adores.When one has traveled the world, has gotten one's heart broken to bits, and has mastered six languages, well, why not dip a toe in the spy game? 28-year-old Anne Catherine Walker, new recruit to the the Farm, is yanked from CIA training with only one month to go and is suddenly thrust into field work. Obviously the CIA has an agenda, and maybe it's not even Annie's polyglot skills that got her initially tapped for the cloak and dagger. It all plays out thru the course of Season One's eleven episodes. We see Annie flounder and make mistakes. But we also see her gain experience and confidence. We see her come of age. Her instincts have always been sound, even if she sometimes dismisses proper protocol.In the world of high stakes espionage, a field agent routinely uses people and in turn is used by them. The phrase "in the interest of transparency" is often utilized by these operatives with an absolute absence of irony. The internal politics are murder and, for Annie, made even more murderous by virtue of her two immediate supervisors (Kari Matchett, Peter Gallagher) working thru their rocky marriage. Sometimes, the CIA's policy of encouraging its staff to keep even their love life within the family can backfire. Annie does make one friend, and I'm sure any number of girlish hearts were set a-flutter once Christopher Gorham entered the scene. Gorham plays Auggie Anderson, the blind ex-Special Forces agent who now runs the CIA's tech ops. Auggie creates an immediate impression. There's instant heat between Gorham and Perabo, and we can't shake the feeling, can't we, that these two's relationship will gradually evolve beyond deep friendship? I don't think it's coincidental that my two favorite episodes are the pilot episode, which introduces Annie Walker, and "Communication Breakdown," in which Auggie is deployed to field work when his hacker ex-girlfriend resurfaces with a coveted new hack.Piper Perabo has got one of the coolest, most distinctive names ever. Having seen her in COYOTE UGLY ages ago and being very much taken with her, I've wondered why she never conquered Hollywood. She's got the goods. She has that mobile, wonderfully expressive face, and I can sense her smarts, and she can act. She deftly navigates the minefield of her role, which calls for her to be naive yet competent, compassionate yet ruthless, intuitive yet in the dark. Maybe the series' weakest element is the hackneyed thru arc which has Annie pining for the mystery gent with whom she once had a fling in Sri Lanka for three weeks, until he abandoned her. I'm guessing you won't be that surprised when you learn how he fits into Annie's current life.COVERT AFFAIRS is spy thriller lite. Interestingly, it takes a mostly positive slant on the CIA. Like its sister shows on USA, it parcels out its share of playfulness. It's not as taut or edgy as 24 or as labyrinthine as ALIAS. Annie Walker isn't as world weary or cynical as BURN NOTICE's Michael Westen. There's stuff here that's been done to death. But I can't stay away from the show. I mean, even the theme song - "Can You Save Me" by Apple Trees and Tangerines - ropes you in. It's not only the chemistry between Perabo and Gorham that's worth noting. They get good support from Gallagher, the icy Matchett, Sendhil Ramamurthy (fresh off HEROES), the ever slimy Gregory Itzin, and Anne Dudek (who plays Annie's long-suffering sister and who's bought into Annie's cover of working for the Smithsonian museum). Anne Dudek is wonderful, by the way, but there's a frustrating element in how often Annie would have to make up an excuse because a mission has just pulled her away from some scheduled sisterly bonding time. Thankfully, this gets resolved in the middle of Season Two.I dig that Annie thinks that "James Bond was a lonely sad old man." I like that she gets her hands dirty but still somehow manages to do the right thing. And, even though she's been trained in martial arts, I like that Annie frequently gets her butt handed to her in life-or-death tussles. It adds believability. But I fear for that day when there won't be a solid object for her to snatch up and wonk the baddie upside the head with. Just one of the perils of covert information wrangling. And Annie Walker, who was thrown abruptly into deep waters, is learning quickly. And all the while looking sexy in a devilish pair of Christian Louboutins (which Auggie mistakenly refers to as "kitten heels").The DVD set's bonus stuff:- Audio Commentaries for 3 episodes: "Pilot" (with Piper Perabo, Christopher Gorham, executive producer Doug Liman, and creators/writers Matt Corman and Chris Ord); "Communication Breakdown" (Piper Perabo, Christopher Gorham, executive producers Dave Bartis and Doug Liman, and creators/writers Matt Corman and Chris Ord); and the season finale "When the Levee Breaks" (Piper Perabo, Christopher Gorham, executive producer Dave Bartis, and creators/writers Matt Corman and Chris Ord)- Deleted Scenes for 6 episodes- Gag Reel (00:02:19 minutes long)- "Welcome to the Farm" - Behind the Scenes of COVERT AFFAIRS, including interviews with the cast & crew (00:13:37 minutes long)- "Blind Insight" - a focus on Auggie and his relationship with Annie; this segment also goes into the various technical devices he operates to help him do his job (00:04:00 minutes)- Set Tour - Sendhil Ramamurthy and creator Matt Corman guide you around the Domestic Protection Division bullpen and Annie's sister's house (00:13:50 minutes)- PSA: Celebrate the ADA (with Chris Gorham; 00:00:38 seconds)
summary: wide-eyed spy craft and erroneous kitten heels

reviewText: Annie (Piper Perabo) gets pulled out of CIA training early because of her needed language skills and is pushed into becoming a field operative. Augie (Chris Gorham), a former CIA field operative who lost his sight during an assignment and now has a high tech desk job, befriends her, guides her and gives much needed aid when she needs it. They form a special bond that enables both to be successful in the CIA. The other characters are, in my opinion, the supporting cast, but the story would be weak without them - lots of plot twists, jealousies and possible romantic liaisons ensue. Annie lives with her sister and her family in a guest house and has to lie about what she does for a living, constantly making up reasons for cuts and bruises she supposedly got while working at the Smithsonian. Unbeknownst to Annie, the CIA is using her to capture her former boyfriend who used to work in the CIA, something she doesn't know about him. He pops up at various locations and saves her from danger or possible death, but always seems to vanish into thin air afterwards. Just your basic story about how a typical girl next door joins the CIA and becomes a success in spite of her lack of a killer instinct.

reviewText: The plot of this TV series is somewhat above-average in theme and action. The acting is sincere and the actors bring out the characters well. I don't know enough about CIA operatives' lives to be able to confirm that the show portrays the reality of their work and their private lives, as the trailer promoted it would be doing, but if it is realistic, I can say that it leaves the viewer with the impression that it is not a job many would aspire to do. It is dangerous, isolating, sometimes depressing, and secretive. Because the show is designed to entertain, I would guess that the role created for Piper Perabo has more pressure, excitement, and action than most agents in real life experience. My understanding is that much of the work in the secret services is behind the scenes and numbly routine. If you are looking for an entertaining action drama online, this one is as good as others similar to it, and it has a subplot to keep you coming back to each new episode.

reviewText: Ok, in essence this show is a revamped version of one of my past favorites:  Alias.  Naive, beautiful, and brilliant college girl gets recruited by the CIA and learns how to kick serious butt.  Then it's a weekly game of "'ok, who's the bad guy today?', the by 'wait, wasn't s/he a good guy in past episodes?', and finally, 'I'm confused, is he or isn't he a bad/good guy?' "  Of course, the once naive, beautiful, and brilliant college girl gradually looses her naiveté and becomes savvy, beautiful, and brilliant CIA girl.  Even though this has all been done before, the writing is good, the acting is good to excellent, and the action scenes are wonderfully exciting.  Piper Perabo does an excellent job carrying this show as the lead actress.  Strangely, she reminds me an awful lot of Jennifer Garner.  Her voice sounds like JG, her smile is often very JG-ish, and of course she's beautiful just like JG.  How bad is that!?  Not very.  I'm addicted and give it two thumbs up.  Would love to see an episode where JG makes a guest appearance!!!

reviewText: It is such a treat to see an entire episode without a commercial break!  This alone is worth the price of admission!  I was very skeptical about this "series" when it was first aired, but the main character that Piper Perabo portrays immediately takes away doubts about the competance of the entire show.  Well cast, well written - IMHO - and certainly a lot more believable than many of the current "spy" shows on the air.If you are one of the few who haven't seen this series about the female CIA operative, then you are truly missing something.  The acting and interaction of the cast is excellent -- the storylines are well done and exciting, and you have a character that someone can really care about -- both from a "will she live through this?" to how well her personal life affects others.The storylines are varied enough to maintain your interest and appreciation.  I see a lot of Spielberg influence here; taking an ordinary, "comfortable" mission and turning into a fight for life -- literally.  This change of pace reflects the real world more than most dramas that I see on TV.  For a TV series the overall look and action is close to NCIS in its scope and effectiveness.  Don't worry Annie -- someone's always got your back!  Can't wait for another season to appear on DVD!
Title: Covert Affairs: Season One
